<p>Celebrating Nowruz at a mall in <a href="/wiki/Tehran" title="Tehran">Tehran</a>, Iran</p>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 162px">
<div style="width: 162px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 160px;">
<div style="margin:0px auto;"><a href="/wiki/File:Nowruz_at_the_Palladium_Mall,_Tehran.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Nowruz_at_the_Palladium_Mall%2C_Tehran.jpg/240px-Nowruz_at_the_Palladium_Mall%2C_Tehran.jpg" width="160" height="120" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Nowruz_at_the_Palladium_Mall%2C_Tehran.jpg/360px-Nowruz_at_the_Palladium_Mall%2C_Tehran.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Nowruz_at_the_Palladium_Mall%2C_Tehran.jpg/480px-Nowruz_at_the_Palladium_Mall%2C_Tehran.jpg 2x" data-file-width="960" data-file-height="720" /></a></div>
</div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p>Traditional setting for Nowruz at a mall in <a href="/wiki/Tehran" title="Tehran">Tehran</a>, Iran</p>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 162px">
<div style="width: 162px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 160px;">
<div style="margin:0px auto;"><a href="/wiki/File:HaftSeen2.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/HaftSeen2.JPG/240px-HaftSeen2.JPG" width="160" height="120" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/HaftSeen2.JPG/360px-HaftSeen2.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/HaftSeen2.JPG/480px-HaftSeen2.JPG 2x" data-file-width="2816" data-file-height="2112" /></a></div>
</div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p><a href="/wiki/Haft_Seen" class="mw-redirect" title="Haft Seen">Haft Seen</a> table in a hotel in <a href="/wiki/Tehran" title="Tehran">Tehran</a>, Iran</p>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 216px">
<div style="width: 216px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 214px;">
<div style="margin:0px auto;"><a href="/wiki/File:People_Singing_EY_IRAN_anthem_@_Persian_New_Year_(Nowruz)_Concert_-_Oberhausen_Arena_-_March_2014.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cf/People_Singing_EY_IRAN_anthem_%40_Persian_New_Year_%28Nowruz%29_Concert_-_Oberhausen_Arena_-_March_2014.png/321px-People_Singing_EY_IRAN_anthem_%40_Persian_New_Year_%28Nowruz%29_Concert_-_Oberhausen_Arena_-_March_2014.png" width="214" height="120" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cf/People_Singing_EY_IRAN_anthem_%40_Persian_New_Year_%28Nowruz%29_Concert_-_Oberhausen_Arena_-_March_2014.png/481px-People_Singing_EY_IRAN_anthem_%40_Persian_New_Year_%28Nowruz%29_Concert_-_Oberhausen_Arena_-_March_2014.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cf/People_Singing_EY_IRAN_anthem_%40_Persian_New_Year_%28Nowruz%29_Concert_-_Oberhausen_Arena_-_March_2014.png/641px-People_Singing_EY_IRAN_anthem_%40_Persian_New_Year_%28Nowruz%29_Concert_-_Oberhausen_Arena_-_March_2014.png 2x" data-file-width="1366" data-file-height="768" /></a></div>
</div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p>Persian New Year Concert in <a href="/wiki/Oberhausen_Arena" class="mw-redirect" title="Oberhausen Arena">Oberhausen Arena</a></p>
</div>
</div>
</li>
</ul>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Azerbaijan">Azerbaijan</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Nowruz&amp;action=edit&amp;section=12" title="Edit section: Azerbaijan">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Novruz_in_Azerbaijan" title="Novruz in Azerbaijan">Novruz in Azerbaijan</a></div>
<p>After Iran, the Republic of Azerbaijan hosts the greatest number of public holidays related to Nowruz, with a total of seven days.<sup id="cite_ref-Azerbaijan_2010_Bank_Holidays_78-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Azerbaijan_2010_Bank_Holidays-78">[78]</a></sup></p>
<p>In Azerbaijan, the holiday goes on for several days and ends with festive public dancing and other entertainment of folk bands, as well as the contests of national sports. In rural areas, crop holidays are also marked.<sup id="cite_ref-96" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-96">[96]</a></sup></p>
<ul class="gallery mw-gallery-packed">
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 91.333333333333px">
<div style="width: 91.333333333333px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 89.333333333333px;">
<div style="margin:0px auto;"><a href="/wiki/File:1996_Novruz_bayram.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/1996_Novruz_bayram.jpg/134px-1996_Novruz_bayram.jpg" width="90" height="120" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/1996_Novruz_bayram.jpg/201px-1996_Novruz_bayram.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/1996_Novruz_bayram.jpg/268px-1996_Novruz_bayram.jpg 2x" data-file-width="473" data-file-height="635" /></a></div>
</div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p>Novruz on an Azerbaijani stamp</p>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 92px">
<div style="width: 92px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 90px;">
<div style="margin:0px auto;"><a href="/wiki/File:%D0%98%D0%B7%D0%BE%D0%B1%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B6%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%B5_1175.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/%D0%98%D0%B7%D0%BE%D0%B1%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B6%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%B5_1175.jpg/135px-%D0%98%D0%B7%D0%BE%D0%B1%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B6%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%B5_1175.jpg" width="90" height="120" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/%D0%98%D0%B7%D0%BE%D0%B1%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B6%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%B5_1175.jpg/203px-%D0%98%D0%B7%D0%BE%D0%B1%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B6%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%B5_1175.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/%D0%98%D0%B7%D0%BE%D0%B1%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B6%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%B5_1175.jpg/270px-%D0%98%D0%B7%D0%BE%D0%B1%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B6%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%B5_1175.jpg 2x" data-file-width="908" data-file-height="1208" /></a></div>
</div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p>Azerbaijani youth celebrating Novruz</p>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 182px">
<div style="width: 182px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 180px;">
<div style="margin:0px auto;"><a href="/wiki/File:NovuzBaku001.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/NovuzBaku001.JPG/270px-NovuzBaku001.JPG" width="180" height="120" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/NovuzBaku001.JPG/405px-NovuzBaku001.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/NovuzBaku001.JPG/540px-NovuzBaku001.JPG 2x" data-file-width="4752" data-file-height="3168" /></a></div>
</div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p>Novruz in <a href="/wiki/Baku" title="Baku">Baku</a>, Azerbaijan</p>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 160px">
<div style="width: 160px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 158px;">
<div style="margin:0px auto;"><a href="/wiki/File:%D0%9D%D0%BE%D0%B2%D1%80%D1%83%D0%B7_%D0%91%D0%B0%D0%BA%D1%83.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/%D0%9D%D0%BE%D0%B2%D1%80%D1%83%D0%B7_%D0%91%D0%B0%D0%BA%D1%83.jpg/237px-%D0%9D%D0%BE%D0%B2%D1%80%D1%83%D0%B7_%D0%91%D0%B0%D0%BA%D1%83.jpg" width="158" height="120" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/%D0%9D%D0%BE%D0%B2%D1%80%D1%83%D0%B7_%D0%91%D0%B0%D0%BA%D1%83.jpg/355px-%D0%9D%D0%BE%D0%B2%D1%80%D1%83%D0%B7_%D0%91%D0%B0%D0%BA%D1%83.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/%D0%9D%D0%BE%D0%B2%D1%80%D1%83%D0%B7_%D0%91%D0%B0%D0%BA%D1%83.jpg/474px-%D0%9D%D0%BE%D0%B2%D1%80%D1%83%D0%B7_%D0%91%D0%B0%D0%BA%D1%83.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1060" data-file-height="806" /></a></div>
</div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p>Novruz festival in <a href="/wiki/Baku" title="Baku">Baku</a>, Azerbaijan</p>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 162px">
<div style="width: 162px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 160px;">
<div style="margin:0px auto;"><a href="/wiki/File:Novruz003.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Novruz003.jpg/240px-Novruz003.jpg" width="160" height="120" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Novruz003.jpg/360px-Novruz003.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Novruz003.jpg/480px-Novruz003.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1167" data-file-height="875" /></a></div>
</div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p>Folk dancers in <a href="/wiki/Baku" title="Baku">Baku</a>, during the Novruz celebrations</p>
</div>
</div>
</li>
</ul>
<p>The Azeri diaspora has communal associations that organize Nowruz celebrations in the <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://azeriamericanews.com/tag/nowruz-holiday/">US and Canada</a> and in <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://vestnikkavkaza.net/articles/society/68622.html">Israel</a></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Afghanistan">Afghanistan</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Nowruz&amp;action=edit&amp;section=13" title="Edit section: Afghanistan">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Nowruz_in_Afghanistan" title="Nowruz in Afghanistan">Nowruz in Afghanistan</a></div>
<p>Nauruz is celebrated widely in <a href="/wiki/Afghanistan" title="Afghanistan">Afghanistan</a>. Also known as the <i>Farmer's Day</i>, the observances usually last two weeks, culminating on the first day of the Afghan New Year, on March 21.<sup id="cite_ref-Goodsell_24-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Goodsell-24">[24]</a></sup> During the Taliban rule (1996–2001), Nauruz was banned and considered "an ancient pagan holiday centered on fire worship".<sup id="cite_ref-97" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-97">[97]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Albania">Albania</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Nowruz&amp;action=edit&amp;section=14" title="Edit section: Albania">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>In <a href="/wiki/Albania" title="Albania">Albania</a>, the day of <i>Sultan Nevruzit</i> is celebrated as a mainly mystical day by the <a href="/wiki/Bektashi" class="mw-redirect" title="Bektashi">Bektashi</a> sect. There are special ceremonies in the <a href="/wiki/Zawiyya" class="mw-redirect" title="Zawiyya">Tekke</a>, led by the clergy, and large meals are served there. They celebrate this day as the birthday of <a href="/wiki/Ali" title="Ali">Ali</a>.</p>
<p>Alongside the religious celebration, all Albanians celebrate a secular version of Nowruz, which is referred to as the <i><a href="/wiki/Spring_Day" title="Spring Day">Spring Day</a></i> (<a href="/wiki/Albanian_language" title="Albanian language">Albanian</a>: <span lang="sq" xml:lang="sq"><i>Dita e Verës</i></span>).</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Armenia">Armenia</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Nowruz&amp;action=edit&amp;section=15" title="Edit section: Armenia">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Since the extinction during the 19th century, Nowruz is not celebrated by <a href="/wiki/Armenians" title="Armenians">Armenians</a> and is not a public holiday in <a href="/wiki/Armenia" title="Armenia">Armenia</a>. However, it is celebrated in Armenia by tens of thousands of Iranian tourists who visit Armenia with relative ease.<sup id="cite_ref-98" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-98">[98]</a></sup> The influx of tourists from Iran accelerated since around 2010–11.<sup id="cite_ref-99" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-99">[99]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-100" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-100">[100]</a></sup> In 2010 alone, around 27,600 Iranians spent Nowruz in capital <a href="/wiki/Yerevan" title="Yerevan">Yerevan</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-101" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-101">[101]</a></sup></p>
<p>In 2015, President <a href="/wiki/Serzh_Sargsyan" title="Serzh Sargsyan">Serzh Sargsyan</a> sent a letter of congratulations to <a href="/wiki/Kurds_in_Armenia" title="Kurds in Armenia">Kurds living in Armenia</a> and to the Iranian political leadership on the occasion of Nowruz.<sup id="cite_ref-102" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-102">[102]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="China">China</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Nowruz&amp;action=edit&amp;section=16" title="Edit section: China">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Traditionally, Nowruz is celebrated mainly in China's <a href="/wiki/Xinjiang_Uyghur_Autonomous_Region" class="mw-redirect" title="Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region">Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region</a> by the <a href="/wiki/Uyghurs" title="Uyghurs">Uyghurs</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tajiks_in_China" class="mw-redirect" title="Tajiks in China">Chinese Tajik</a>, Salar, and <a href="/wiki/Kazakhs" title="Kazakhs">Kazakh</a> ethnicities.<sup id="cite_ref-xinhuanet.com_3-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-xinhuanet.com-3">[3]</a></sup></p>
<p>It's a tradition for people to plant trees, dredge irrigation canals, clean houses and prepare scrumptious food for guests during the festival.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (May 2015)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Georgia">Georgia</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Nowruz&amp;action=edit&amp;section=17" title="Edit section: Georgia">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Nowruz is not celebrated by <a href="/wiki/Georgians" title="Georgians">Georgians</a> (excluding those who live in <a href="/wiki/Iranian_Georgians" title="Iranian Georgians">Iran</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ingiloy_people" title="Ingiloy people">Azerbaijan</a>), but it has become a public holiday in <a href="/wiki/Georgia_(country)" title="Georgia (country)">Georgia</a> since 2010. It is widely celebrated by the country's large <a href="/wiki/Azerbaijanis_in_Georgia" title="Azerbaijanis in Georgia">Azerbaijani minority</a> (~7% of the total population)<sup id="cite_ref-agenda.ge_103-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-agenda.ge-103">[103]</a></sup> as well as by the <a href="/wiki/Iran" title="Iran">Iranians</a> living in Georgia.<sup id="cite_ref-agenda.ge_103-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-agenda.ge-103">[103]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-104" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-104">[104]</a></sup> Most Georgian Azerbaijanis live in <a href="/wiki/Kvemo_Kartli" title="Kvemo Kartli">Kvemo Kartli</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kakheti" title="Kakheti">Kakheti</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shida_Kartli" title="Shida Kartli">Shida Kartli</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Mtskheta-Mtianeti" title="Mtskheta-Mtianeti">Mtskheta-Mtianeti</a> regions. In addition, there is also a large historical Azerbaijani community in the capital city of Tbilisi, thus marking these as the core regions of celebration in Georgia.<sup id="cite_ref-agenda.ge_103-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-agenda.ge-103">[103]</a></sup> Every year, large festivities are held notably in the capital <a href="/wiki/Tbilisi" title="Tbilisi">Tbilisi</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-agenda.ge_103-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-agenda.ge-103">[103]</a></sup> Georgian politicians have attended the festivities in the capital over the years, and have congratulated the Nowruz-observing ethnic groups and nationals in Georgia on the day of Nowruz.<sup id="cite_ref-105" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-105">[105]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-106" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-106">[106]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Kurds">Kurds</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Nowruz&amp;action=edit&amp;section=18" title="Edit section: Kurds">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Newroz_as_celebrated_by_Kurds" title="Newroz as celebrated by Kurds">Newroz as celebrated by Kurds</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Newroz_Istanbul(5).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Newroz_Istanbul%285%29.jpg/220px-Newroz_Istanbul%285%29.jpg" width="220" height="181" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Newroz_Istanbul%285%29.jpg/330px-Newroz_Istanbul%285%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Newroz_Istanbul%285%29.jpg/440px-Newroz_Istanbul%285%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2484" data-file-height="2048" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Newroz_Istanbul(5).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
Newroz in <a href="/wiki/Istanbul" title="Istanbul">Istanbul</a>, <a href="/wiki/Turkey" title="Turkey">Turkey</a></div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Newroz (or <i>Nevruz</i>) is largely considered as a potent symbol of Kurdish identity in <a href="/wiki/Turkey" title="Turkey">Turkey</a>, even if there are some <a href="/wiki/Turkish_people" title="Turkish people">Turks</a> (including Turkmens) celebrating the festival. The Kurds of Turkey celebrate this feast between 18th till 21 March. Kurds gather into fairgrounds mostly outside the cities to welcome spring. Women wear colored dresses and spangled head scarves and young men wave flags of green, yellow and red, the historic colors of Kurdish people. They hold this festival by lighting fire and dancing around it.<sup id="cite_ref-107" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-107">[107]</a></sup> Newroz celebrations are usually organised by Kurdish cultural associations and pro-Kurdish political parties. Thus, the <a href="/wiki/Democratic_Society_Party" title="Democratic Society Party">Democratic Society Party</a> was a leading force in the organisation of the 2006 Newroz events throughout Turkey. In recent years, the Newroz celebration gathers around 1 million participants in <a href="/wiki/Diyarbak%C4%B1r" title="Diyarbakr">Diyarbakr</a>, the biggest city of the Kurdish dominated Southeastern Turkey. As the Kurdish Newroz celebrations in Turkey often are theater for political messages, the events are frequently criticized for being political rallies rather than cultural celebrations.</p>
<p>Until 2005, the Kurdish population of Turkey could not celebrate their New Year openly.<sup id="cite_ref-108" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-108">[108]</a></sup> "Thousands of people have been detained in Turkey, as the authorities take action against suspected supporters of the Kurdish rebel movement, the PKK.<sup id="cite_ref-109" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-109">[109]</a></sup> The holiday is now official in Turkey after international pressure on the Turkish government to lift culture bans. Turkish government renamed the holiday <i>Nevroz</i> in 1995.<sup id="cite_ref-110" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-110">[110]</a></sup> In the recent years, limitations on expressions of Kurdish national identity, including the usage of <a href="/wiki/Kurdish_languages" title="Kurdish languages">Kurdish</a> in the public sphere, have been considerably relaxed.</p>
<p>On 21 March 2013, PKK leader <a href="/wiki/Abdullah_Ocalan" class="mw-redirect" title="Abdullah Ocalan">Abdullah Ocalan</a> called for a ceasefire through a message that was released in <a href="/wiki/Diyarbak%C4%B1r" title="Diyarbakr">Diyarbakr</a> during the Newroz celebrations.<sup id="cite_ref-Ocalan_calls_for_ceasefire_111-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ocalan_calls_for_ceasefire-111">[111]</a></sup></p>
<p>In Syria, the Kurds dress up in their national dress and celebrate the New Year.<sup id="cite_ref-112" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-112">[112]</a></sup> According to Human Rights Watch, the Kurds have had to struggle to celebrate Newroz, and in the past the celebration has led to violent oppression, leading to several deaths and mass arrests.<sup id="cite_ref-113" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-113">[113]</a></sup> The government has stated that the Newroz celebrations will be tolerated as long as they do not become political demonstrations of the treatment of the Kurds.<sup id="cite_ref-Yildiz_114-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Yildiz-114">[114]</a></sup> During the Newroz celebrations in 2008, three Kurds were shot dead by Syrian security forces.<sup id="cite_ref-115" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-115">[115]</a></sup> <sup id="cite_ref-116" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-116">[116]</a></sup></p>
<p>Kurds in the <a href="/wiki/Diaspora" title="Diaspora">diaspora</a> also celebrate the New Year; for example, Kurds in Australia celebrate Newroz, not only as the beginning of the new year, but also as the Kurdish National Day. The Kurds in Finland celebrate the new year as a way of demonstrating their support for the Kurdish cause.<sup id="cite_ref-117" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-117">[117]</a></sup> Also in London, organizers estimated that 25000 people celebrated Newroz during March 2006.<sup id="cite_ref-118" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-118">[118]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Pakistan">Pakistan</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Nowruz&amp;action=edit&amp;section=19" title="Edit section: Pakistan">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Nowruz celebrations are observed by some of the ethnic groups in Pakistan, such as the Pashtuns and Baloch people. It may last weeks,<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (March 2016)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> particularly in the states of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa and Balochistan, from where the largest groups of Pakistan's Iranian-speaking people originate from (Pashtuns and Balochis respectively).</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Parsis_.28Indian_subcontinent.29">Parsis (Indian subcontinent)</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Nowruz&amp;action=edit&amp;section=20" title="Edit section: Parsis (Indian subcontinent)">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>The Parsi New Year is celebrated as <i>Jamshed Navroz</i> by the entire <a href="/wiki/Parsi" title="Parsi">Parsi</a> community across the world. The festival falls on the first day of the first month of the <a href="/wiki/Fasli_calendar" class="mw-redirect" title="Fasli calendar">Fasli calendar</a>, followed by the Parsis.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (June 2015)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> This falls in the month of March, according to the <a href="/wiki/Gregorian_calendar" title="Gregorian calendar">Gregorian calendar</a>. As the day commences with the advent of spring or the vernal equinox, Jamshed Navroz is celebrated with immense fun and fervor. Zoroastrian Parsis observe the festival by performing the rituals and rites with full devotion and duty. A particular sect of Parsis resides in the western part of India and hence, Jamshed Navroz celebrations can be prominently noticed in these regions.</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Observances">Observances</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Nowruz&amp;action=edit&amp;section=21" title="Edit section: Observances">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="House_cleaning_and_shopping">House cleaning and shopping</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Nowruz&amp;action=edit&amp;section=22" title="Edit section: House cleaning and shopping">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Spring_cleaning" title="Spring cleaning">Spring cleaning</a></div>
<p>House cleaning, or <i>shaking the house</i> (<span lang="fa" xml:lang="fa"> </span> – <span title="Persian transliteration" class="Unicode" style="white-space:normal; text-decoration: none"><i>xane tekni</i></span>) as referred to by Persian-speaking Iranians, is commonly observed before the arrival of Nowruz. People start preparing for Nowruz with a major spring-cleaning of their house and the purchase of new clothes to wear for the New Year, as well the purchase of flowers. In particular, the <a href="/wiki/Hyacinth_(plant)" title="Hyacinth (plant)">hyacinth</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Tulip" title="Tulip">tulip</a> are popular and conspicuous.</p>
<p>In association with the "rebirth of nature", extensive spring cleaning is a national tradition observed by almost every household in Iran. This is also extended to personal attire, and it is customary to buy at least one set of new clothes.</p>
<p>Parsis adorn their houses with different auspicious symbols; namely, stars, butterflies, birds and fish. They order and make new attires especially for the festival. On the day of Navroz, they dress in their new and best clothes and put on gold and silver kustis and caps. They decorate the doors and windows with garlands of roses and jasmines, and use color powders for creating patterns known as <i>rangoli</i> on the steps and thresholds. Fish and floral motifs are a favorite among rangolis and considered highly auspicious.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (June 2015)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Festival_of_Charshanbe_Suri">Festival of Charshanbe Suri</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Nowruz&amp;action=edit&amp;section=23" title="Edit section: Festival of Charshanbe Suri">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Chaharshanbe_Suri" title="Chaharshanbe Suri">Charshanbe Suri</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Chaharshanbe_Suri_Lozupone_NYC_2016_1.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/Chaharshanbe_Suri_Lozupone_NYC_2016_1.png/220px-Chaharshanbe_Suri_Lozupone_NYC_2016_1.png" width="220" height="191" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/Chaharshanbe_Suri_Lozupone_NYC_2016_1.png/330px-Chaharshanbe_Suri_Lozupone_NYC_2016_1.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/Chaharshanbe_Suri_Lozupone_NYC_2016_1.png/440px-Chaharshanbe_Suri_Lozupone_NYC_2016_1.png 2x" data-file-width="2490" data-file-height="2159" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Chaharshanbe_Suri_Lozupone_NYC_2016_1.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<a href="/wiki/Charshanbe_Suri" class="mw-redirect" title="Charshanbe Suri">Charshanbe Suri</a> in <a href="/wiki/New_York_City" title="New York City">New York City</a>, March 2016</div>
</div>
</div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Charshanbe_Suri" class="mw-redirect" title="Charshanbe Suri">Charshanbe Suri</a> (<a href="/wiki/Persian_language" title="Persian language">Persian</a>: <span lang="fa" dir="rtl" xml:lang="fa"> </span> – <span title="Persian transliteration" class="Unicode" style="white-space:normal; text-decoration: none"><i>ršanbe Suri</i></span>; <a href="/wiki/Kurdish_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Kurdish language">Kurdish</a>: <span lang="ku" dir="rtl" xml:lang="ku"><i>Çarema Sor</i></span>; <a href="/wiki/Azerbaijani_language" title="Azerbaijani language">Azerbaijani</a>: <span lang="az" xml:lang="az"><i>Çrnb Bayram</i></span>) is a prelude to the New Year. In Iran, it is celebrated on the eve of the last Wednesday before Nowruz. It is usually celebrated in the evening, and is obtained by people making bonfires and jumping over them, as well as setting off <a href="/wiki/Fireworks" title="Fireworks">fireworks</a> and sparklers.</p>
<p>In Azerbaijan, where the preparation for Novruz usually begins a month earlier, the festival is held every Tuesday during four weeks before the holiday of Novruz. Each Tuesday, people celebrate the day of one of the four elements&#160;– water, fire, earth and wind.<sup id="cite_ref-nowaze_119-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nowaze-119">[119]</a></sup> On the holiday eve, the graves of relatives are visited and tended.<sup id="cite_ref-120" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-120">[120]</a></sup></p>
<p>Iranians sing the traditional poetic quote <i>zardi ye man az to, sorkhi ye to az man</i> during the festival, which literally means "my yellow is yours, your red is mine"; meaning you want the fire to replace your pallor, sickness, and problems with warmth and energy. <a href="/wiki/Trail_mix" title="Trail mix">Trail mix</a> and <a href="/wiki/Berries" class="mw-redirect" title="Berries">berries</a> are also served during the celebration.</p>
<p>Spoon hitting (<span lang="fa" xml:lang="fa"> </span> – <span title="Persian transliteration" class="Unicode" style="white-space:normal; text-decoration: none"><i>qšoq zani</i></span>) is an Iranian tradition observed on the eve of Charshanbe Suri, which is similar to the <a href="/wiki/Halloween" title="Halloween">Halloween</a> custom <a href="/wiki/Trick-or-treating" title="Trick-or-treating">Trick-or-treating</a>. It is practiced by people wearing <a href="/wiki/Disguise" title="Disguise">disguises</a> and going door-to-door to bang spoons against plates or bowls and receive packaged <a href="/wiki/Snack" title="Snack">snacks</a>.</p>
<p>In Azerbaijan, according to old traditions, children slip around to their neighbors' homes and apartments on the last Tuesday prior to Novruz, knock at the doors, and leave their caps or little basket on the thresholds all the while hiding nearby waiting for candies, pastries and nuts.<sup id="cite_ref-nowaze_119-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nowaze-119">[119]</a></sup></p>
<p>The ritual of jumping over fire has remained in Armenia in the feast of <i><a href="/wiki/Trndez" title="Trndez">Trndez</a></i>, which is a feast of purification in the <a href="/wiki/Armenian_Apostolic_Church" title="Armenian Apostolic Church">Armenian Apostolic Church</a> and <a href="/wiki/Armenian_Catholic_Church" title="Armenian Catholic Church">Armenian Catholic Churches</a>, celebrated forty days after <a href="/wiki/Jesus" title="Jesus">Jesus</a>'s birth.<sup id="cite_ref-121" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-121">[121]</a></sup></p>
<p>Among the <a href="/wiki/Yazidis" title="Yazidis">Yazidis</a>, this festival is celebrated on the first Wednesday of Nisan (April) which marks their New Year's Day.</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Festivals_of_Gul-i-Surkh_and_Dehq.C4.81n">Festivals of Gul-i-Surkh and Dehqn</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Nowruz&amp;action=edit&amp;section=24" title="Edit section: Festivals of Gul-i-Surkh and Dehqn">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>In Afghanistan, the festival of Gul-i-Surkh (<a href="/wiki/Dari_language" title="Dari language">Dari</a>: <span lang="prs" dir="rtl" xml:lang="prs"> </span>; "Red Flower," referring to red <a href="/wiki/Tulip" title="Tulip">tulip</a> flowers) is the principal festival for Nauruz. It is celebrated in <a href="/wiki/Mazar-i-Sharif" title="Mazar-i-Sharif">Mazar-i-Sharif</a> during the first 40 days of the year, when the tulip flowers grow in the green plains and over the hills surrounding the city. People from all over the country travel to Mazar-i-Sharif to attend the Nauruz festivals. Various activities and customs are performed during the Gul-i-Surkh festival, including:</p>
<ul>
<li><i>Jahenda Bala</i> (<a href="/wiki/Dari_language" title="Dari language">Dari</a>: <span lang="prs" dir="rtl" xml:lang="prs"> </span>; "Raising"), which is celebrated on the first day of the New Year,<sup id="cite_ref-122" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-122">[122]</a></sup> and is attended by high-ranking government officials such as the Vice-President, Ministers, and Provincial Governors – It is a specific religious ceremony performed at the <a href="/wiki/Shrine_of_Ali" title="Shrine of Ali">Blue Mosque</a> of Mazar-i-Sharif. The ceremony is performed by raising a special banner whose color configuration resembles <a href="/wiki/Derafsh_Kaviani" title="Derafsh Kaviani">Derafsh Kaviani</a>. This is the biggest recorded Nawroz gathering where up to 200,000 people from all over Afghanistan get together to celebrate the ceremony.</li>
<li><i><a href="/wiki/Buzkashi" title="Buzkashi">Buzkashi</a></i> tournament, held during the Gul-i-Surkh festival in Mazar-i-Sharif, <a href="/wiki/Kabul" title="Kabul">Kabul</a> and other northern cities of Afghanistan</li>
</ul>
<p>The festival of <i>Dehqn</i> (<a href="/wiki/Dari_language" title="Dari language">Dari</a>: <span lang="prs" dir="rtl" xml:lang="prs"></span>; "Farmer") is celebrated on the first day of the New Year, in which the farmers walk in the cities as a sign of encouragement for the agricultural productions. In recent years, this activity is being performed only in Kabul and other major cities of Afghanistan, in which the mayor and other high governmental personalities participate for watching and observing.</p>
<p>The citizens of <a href="/wiki/Kabul" title="Kabul">Kabul</a> go to <a href="/wiki/Istalif" title="Istalif">Istalif</a>, <a href="/wiki/Charikar" title="Charikar">Charikar</a> or other green places around where the <a href="/wiki/Cercis" title="Cercis">Cercis</a> flowers grow. They go for picnic with their families during the first two weeks of the New Year.</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Decorative_tables">Decorative tables</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Nowruz&amp;action=edit&amp;section=25" title="Edit section: Decorative tables">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Haft_Seen">Haft Seen</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Nowruz&amp;action=edit&amp;section=26" title="Edit section: Haft Seen">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Haft_Seen" class="mw-redirect" title="Haft Seen">Haft Seen</a></div>
<p>Haft Seen (<a href="/wiki/Persian_language" title="Persian language">Persian</a>: <span lang="fa" dir="rtl" xml:lang="fa"> </span> – <span title="Persian transliteration" class="Unicode" style="white-space:normal; text-decoration: none"><i>Haft Sin</i></span>); "Seven S's") is the traditional <a href="/wiki/Table_setting" title="Table setting">table setting</a> of Nowruz in Iran. Typically, before the arrival of Nowruz, family members gather around a table, with the Haft Seen set on it, and await the exact moment of the <a href="/wiki/March_equinox" title="March equinox">March equinox</a> to celebrate the New Year. At that time, the New Year gifts are exchanged.</p>
<p>The setting includes seven items starting with the letter <i>S</i> or <i>seen</i> (<span lang="fa" xml:lang="fa"></span>) in the <a href="/wiki/Persian_alphabet" title="Persian alphabet">Perso-Arabic alphabet</a>. The items include:</p>
<ul>
<li>Greenery (<span lang="fa" xml:lang="fa"></span> – <span title="Persian transliteration" class="Unicode" style="white-space:normal; text-decoration: none"><i>sabze</i></span>): <a href="/wiki/Wheat" title="Wheat">Wheat</a>, <a href="/wiki/Barley" title="Barley">barley</a> or <a href="/wiki/Lentil" title="Lentil">lentil</a> sprouts grown in a dish</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Samanu" title="Samanu">Samanu</a> (<span lang="fa" xml:lang="fa"></span> – <span title="Persian transliteration" class="Unicode" style="white-space:normal; text-decoration: none"><i>samanu</i></span>): A sweet pudding made from germinated wheat</li>
<li>The dried fruit of the <a href="/wiki/Elaeagnus_angustifolia" title="Elaeagnus angustifolia">oleaster</a> tree (<span lang="fa" xml:lang="fa"></span> – <span title="Persian transliteration" class="Unicode" style="white-space:normal; text-decoration: none"><i>senjed</i></span>)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Garlic" title="Garlic">Garlic</a> (<span lang="fa" xml:lang="fa"></span> – <span title="Persian transliteration" class="Unicode" style="white-space:normal; text-decoration: none"><i>sir</i></span>)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Apples" class="mw-redirect" title="Apples">Apples</a> (<span lang="fa" xml:lang="fa"></span> – <span title="Persian transliteration" class="Unicode" style="white-space:normal; text-decoration: none"><i>sib</i></span>)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Sumac" title="Sumac">Sumac</a> berries (<span lang="fa" xml:lang="fa"></span> – <span title="Persian transliteration" class="Unicode" style="white-space:normal; text-decoration: none"><i>somq</i></span>)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Vinegar" title="Vinegar">Vinegar</a> (<span lang="fa" xml:lang="fa"></span> – <span title="Persian transliteration" class="Unicode" style="white-space:normal; text-decoration: none"><i>serke</i></span>)</li>
</ul>
<p>These items are also known to have astrological correlations to planets Mercury, Venus, Mars, Jupiter, Saturn, Sun and Moon.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (March 2017)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup></p>
<p>Other symbolic items which are usually set along the Haft Seen are <a href="/wiki/Candle" title="Candle">candles</a>, a mirror, decorating coins, and <a href="/wiki/Egg_decorating" title="Egg decorating">decorated eggs</a> (sometimes one for each member of the family). A bowl of water with <a href="/wiki/Goldfish" title="Goldfish">goldfish</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-123" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-123">[123]</a></sup> a holy book (e.g. the <a href="/wiki/Avesta" title="Avesta">Avesta</a> or <a href="/wiki/Quran" title="Quran">Quran</a>) and/or a poetry book (e.g. the Divan of <a href="/wiki/Hafez" title="Hafez">Hafez</a>), and <a href="/wiki/Rose_water" title="Rose water">rose water</a> are also included to the setting.</p>
<p>The custom and the traditional practice of Haft Seen has been changed over times. The initial term <i>Haft Chin</i> meaning "the seven collected", has been gradually altered to the present-day name of the setting.</p>
<ul class="gallery mw-gallery-packed">
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 215.33333333333px">

</div>
</div>
</li>
</ul>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Haft_Mewa">Haft Mewa</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Nowruz&amp;action=edit&amp;section=27" title="Edit section: Haft Mewa">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<p>In Afghanistan, people prepare Haft Mewa (<a href="/wiki/Dari_language" title="Dari language">Dari</a>: <span lang="prs" dir="rtl" xml:lang="prs"> </span> – <span title="Dari transliteration" class="Unicode" style="white-space:normal; text-decoration: none"><i>Haft Mwa</i></span>; literally "the Seven Fruits") for the New Year's Day. It is similar to a <a href="/wiki/Fruit_salad" title="Fruit salad">fruit salad</a>, and is made from seven different <a href="/wiki/Dried_fruit" title="Dried fruit">dried fruits</a> served in their own <a href="/wiki/Syrup" title="Syrup">syrup</a>.</p>
<p>The seven dried fruits prepared for the Haft Mewa setting include:</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="/wiki/Raisin" title="Raisin">Raisin</a></li>
<li>Senjed, the dried fruit of the <a href="/wiki/Elaeagnus_angustifolia" title="Elaeagnus angustifolia">oleaster</a> tree.</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Pistachio" title="Pistachio">Pistachio</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Common_Hazel" class="mw-redirect" title="Common Hazel">Hazelnut</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Prune_(fruit)" class="mw-redirect" title="Prune (fruit)">Prune</a>, the dry fruit of <a href="/wiki/Apricot" title="Apricot">apricot</a>.</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Walnut" title="Walnut">Walnut</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Almond" title="Almond">Almond</a> or other species of <a href="/wiki/Plum" title="Plum">plum</a> fruits.</li>
</ul>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Khoncha">Khoncha</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Nowruz&amp;action=edit&amp;section=28" title="Edit section: Khoncha">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<p>In Azerbaijan, the decoration of the festive table is called <i>Khoncha</i> (<a href="/wiki/Azerbaijani_language" title="Azerbaijani language">Azerbaijani</a>: <span lang="az" xml:lang="az"><i>Xonça</i></span>). It consists of a big silver or copper tray, with <a href="/wiki/Samani" title="Samani">Samani</a> placed in the center, as well as candles and dyed eggs by the number of family members around it.</p>
<p>The table should be set, at least, with seven dishes.<sup id="cite_ref-nowaze_119-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nowaze-119">[119]</a></sup></p>
<ul class="gallery mw-gallery-packed">
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 162px">
<div style="width: 162px">

</li>

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Traditional_heralds">Traditional heralds</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Nowruz&amp;action=edit&amp;section=29" title="Edit section: Traditional heralds">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Amu_Nowruz_and_Haji_Firuz">Amu Nowruz and Haji Firuz</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Nowruz&amp;action=edit&amp;section=30" title="Edit section: Amu Nowruz and Haji Firuz">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Amu_Nowruz" title="Amu Nowruz">Amu Nowruz</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hajji_Firuz" title="Hajji Firuz">Hajji Firuz</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Amu_Nowruz.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Amu_Nowruz.jpg/170px-Amu_Nowruz.jpg" width="170" height="201" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Amu_Nowruz.jpg/255px-Amu_Nowruz.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Amu_Nowruz.jpg/340px-Amu_Nowruz.jpg 2x" data-file-width="638" data-file-height="756" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Amu_Nowruz.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<a href="/wiki/Amu_Nowruz" title="Amu Nowruz">Amu Nowruz</a></div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Haji_Firuz_on_the_road.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Haji_Firuz_on_the_road.jpg/220px-Haji_Firuz_on_the_road.jpg" width="220" height="161" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Haji_Firuz_on_the_road.jpg/330px-Haji_Firuz_on_the_road.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Haji_Firuz_on_the_road.jpg/440px-Haji_Firuz_on_the_road.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3920" data-file-height="2872" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Haji_Firuz_on_the_road.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<a href="/wiki/Hajji_Firuz" title="Hajji Firuz">Haji Firuz</a> performers on a road to <a href="/wiki/Tehran" title="Tehran">Tehran</a>.</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>In Iran, the traditional heralds of the festival of Nowruz are <a href="/wiki/Amu_Nowruz" title="Amu Nowruz">Amu Nowruz</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hajji_Firuz" title="Hajji Firuz">Haji Firuz</a>, who appear annually in the streets to celebrate the New Year.</p>
<p>Amu Nowruz brings children gifts, much like his <a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">Christian</a> counterpart <a href="/wiki/Santa_Claus" title="Santa Claus">Santa Claus</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-124" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-124">[124]</a></sup> He is the husband of <a href="/wiki/Nane_Sarma" title="Nane Sarma">Nane Sarma</a>, with whom he shares a traditional love story in which they can meet each other only once a year.<sup id="cite_ref-125" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-125">[125]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-126" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-126">[126]</a></sup> He is characterized as an elderly silver-haired man who puts on a felt hat, and has a walking stick, a long cloak of blue canvas, a sash, a pair of thin-soled <a href="/wiki/Giveh" title="Giveh">giveh</a>, and a pair of linen trousers.<sup id="cite_ref-127" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-127">[127]</a></sup></p>
<p>Haji Firuz, a blackface character clad in bright red clothes and a felt hat, is the companion of Amu Nowruz. He dances through the streets while singing and playing a tambourine. In the traditional songs, he introduces himself as a serf trying to cheer people who he refers to as his lords. As a blackface serf, it is a controversial character, seen as symbolically racist.<sup id="cite_ref-128" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-128">[128]</a></sup> Therefore, half of his face is sometimes painted white in order to prevent the criticisms.</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Kampirak">Kampirak</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Nowruz&amp;action=edit&amp;section=31" title="Edit section: Kampirak">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<p>In the folklore of Afghanistan, Kampirak and his retinue pass village by village distributing gathered charities among people. He is an old bearded man wearing colorful clothes with a long hat and rosary who symbolizes beneficence and the power of nature yielding the forces of winter. The tradition is observed in central provinces, specially <a href="/wiki/Bamyan_Province" title="Bamyan Province">Bamyan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Daykundi_Province" title="Daykundi Province">Daykundi</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-129" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-129">[129]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Visiting_one_another">Visiting one another</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Nowruz&amp;action=edit&amp;section=32" title="Edit section: Visiting one another">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>During the Nowruz holidays, people are expected to visit one another (mostly limited to families, friends and neighbors) in the form of short house visits, which are usually reciprocated. Typically, the youth will visit the elders first, and the elders return their visit later.</p>
<p>In Iran, the visits naturally have to be relatively short, otherwise one will not be able to visit everybody on the list. A typical visit is lesser than 30 minutes, where you often run into other visiting relatives and friends who happen to be paying a visit to the same house at that time.</p>
<p>Because of the house visits, you make sure you have a sufficient supply of pastry, cookies, fresh and dried fruits and mixed nuts on hand, as you typically serve your visitors with these items with tea and other beverages. Many Iranians will throw large Nowruz parties in a central location as a way of dealing with the long distances between groups of friends and family.</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sizdebedar">Sizdebedar</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Nowruz&amp;action=edit&amp;section=33" title="Edit section: Sizdebedar">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Sizdah_Be-dar" title="Sizdah Be-dar">Sizdebedar</a></div>
<p>In Iran, the Nowruz holidays last thirteen days. On the thirteenth day of the New Year, Iranians leave their houses to join nature and <a href="/wiki/Picnic" title="Picnic">picnic outdoors</a>, as part of the <a href="/wiki/Sizdah_Be-dar" title="Sizdah Be-dar">Sizdebedar</a> ceremony.</p>
<p>On the day of Sizdebedar, the greenery grown for the <a href="/wiki/Haft_Seen" class="mw-redirect" title="Haft Seen">Haft Seen</a> setting is thrown away, particularly into a running water. It is also customary for young single people, especially young girls, to tie the leaves of the greenery before discarding it, expressing a wish to find a partner.</p>
<p>Another custom associated with Sizdebedar is <i>Lie of the Thirteen</i>, which is the process of lying to someone and making them believe it.<sup id="cite_ref-130" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-130">[130]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-131" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-131">[131]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-132" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-132">[132]</a></sup> It has been directly borrowed from <a href="/wiki/April_Fools%27_Day" title="April Fools' Day">April Fools' Day</a>, and has become in vogue in Iran due to its coincidence with the day of the celebration of Sizdebedar.</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cuisine">Cuisine</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Nowruz&amp;action=edit&amp;section=34" title="Edit section: Cuisine">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Baklava_-_Turkish_special,_80-ply.JPEG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Baklava_-_Turkish_special%2C_80-ply.JPEG/170px-Baklava_-_Turkish_special%2C_80-ply.JPEG" width="170" height="113" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Baklava_-_Turkish_special%2C_80-ply.JPEG/255px-Baklava_-_Turkish_special%2C_80-ply.JPEG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Baklava_-_Turkish_special%2C_80-ply.JPEG/340px-Baklava_-_Turkish_special%2C_80-ply.JPEG 2x" data-file-width="1542" data-file-height="1024" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Baklava_-_Turkish_special,_80-ply.JPEG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>

</div>
</div>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Sabzi_polo.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Sabzi_polo.jpg/170px-Sabzi_polo.jpg" width="170" height="132" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Sabzi_polo.jpg/255px-Sabzi_polo.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Sabzi_polo.jpg/340px-Sabzi_polo.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3676" data-file-height="2848" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Sabzi_polo.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<a href="/wiki/Sabzi_polo" title="Sabzi polo">Sabzi polow</a></div>
</div>
</div>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Desserts_and_snacks">Desserts and snacks</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Nowruz&amp;action=edit&amp;section=35" title="Edit section: Desserts and snacks">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<ul>
<li>Ajil (<a href="/wiki/Kurds" title="Kurds">Kurds</a>, <a href="/wiki/Persian_people" title="Persian people">Persians</a>): <a href="/wiki/Trail_mix" title="Trail mix">Trail mix</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Baklava" title="Baklava">Baklava</a> (<a href="/wiki/Azerbaijanis" title="Azerbaijanis">Azerbaijanis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Persian_people" title="Persian people">Persians</a>, <a href="/wiki/Turkish_people" title="Turkish people">Turks</a>): A flaky pastry filled with walnuts, almonds or pistachios, and flavored with rosewater</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Falooda" title="Falooda">Falooda</a> dessert (<a href="/wiki/Parsi" title="Parsi">Parsis</a>): A sweet milk drink made from vermicelli and flavored with rose essence</li>
<li>Lagan-nu-custard dessert (<a href="/wiki/Parsi" title="Parsi">Parsis</a>): A type of <a href="/wiki/Cr%C3%A8me_caramel" title="Crème caramel">caramel custard</a>.</li>
<li>Nan berenji (<a href="/wiki/Iran" title="Iran">Iranians</a>): Cookies made from <a href="/wiki/Rice_flour" title="Rice flour">rice flour</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Noghl" title="Noghl">Noql</a> (<a href="/wiki/Pashtuns" title="Pashtuns">Pashtuns</a>, <a href="/wiki/Persian_people" title="Persian people">Persians</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tajiks" title="Tajiks">Tajiks</a>): Sugar-coated almonds</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Samanu" title="Samanu">Samanu</a> (<a href="/wiki/Azerbaijanis" title="Azerbaijanis">Azerbaijanis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kurds" title="Kurds">Kurds</a>, <a href="/wiki/Persian_people" title="Persian people">Persians</a>): Sprouted wheat pudding</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Shekerbura" title="Shekerbura">Shekerbura</a> (<a href="/wiki/Azerbaijanis" title="Azerbaijanis">Azerbaijanis</a>): Azerbaijani sweet pastries</li>
<li>Shorgoghal (<a href="/wiki/Azerbaijanis" title="Azerbaijanis">Azerbaijanis</a>): Flaky bread with a spice filling</li>
</ul>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Dishes">Dishes</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Nowruz&amp;action=edit&amp;section=36" title="Edit section: Dishes">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<ul>
<li><a href="/wiki/Ash_reshteh" title="Ash reshteh">Ash e reshte</a> (<a href="/wiki/Iran" title="Iran">Iranians</a>): A noodle soup traditionally served on the first day of Nowruz.<sup id="cite_ref-133" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-133">[133]</a></sup></li>
<li>Chicken farcha (<a href="/wiki/Parsi" title="Parsi">Parsis</a>): A typical Parsi dish of fried chicken.</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Dolma" title="Dolma">Dolma</a> (<a href="/wiki/Azerbaijanis" title="Azerbaijanis">Azerbaijanis</a>): A traditional dish of Azeri people, cooked just before the New Year. It includes vegetables, meat and rice which have been cooked, then rolled in grape leaves and cooked again.</li>
<li>Fried fish and jelabi (<a href="/wiki/Afghanistan" title="Afghanistan">Afghans</a>): The most often meal of the Nauruz picnics in Afghanistan.</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Kuku_(food)" title="Kuku (food)">Kuku sabzi</a> (<a href="/wiki/Iran" title="Iran">Iranians</a>): Herbs and vegetable <a href="/wiki/Souffl%C3%A9" title="Soufflé">soufflé</a>, traditionally served for dinner on New Year's. It is a light and fluffy omelet made with parsley, dill herb, coriander greens (cilantro), <a href="/wiki/Spinach" title="Spinach">spinach</a>, <a href="/wiki/Spring_onion" class="mw-redirect" title="Spring onion">spring onion</a> leaves and chives, mixed with eggs and <a href="/wiki/Walnut" title="Walnut">walnuts</a>.</li>
<li>Kulcha-e Nauruz (<a href="/wiki/Pashtuns" title="Pashtuns">Pashtuns</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tajiks" title="Tajiks">Tajiks</a>): Afghan rice cookies which are only baked for Nauruz.</li>
<li>Nawrz koje (<a href="/wiki/Kazakhs" title="Kazakhs">Kazakhs</a>): A traditional New Year's Day dish of the Kazakh people, which includes water, meat, salt, flour, grain and milk.</li>
<li>Reshte polow (<a href="/wiki/Iran" title="Iran">Iranians</a>): Rice cooked with noodles.</li>
<li>Sabzi chalaw (<a href="/wiki/Pashtuns" title="Pashtuns">Pashtuns</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tajiks" title="Tajiks">Tajiks</a>): A dish made from rice and <a href="/wiki/Spinach" title="Spinach">spinach</a>.</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Sabzi_polo" title="Sabzi polo">Sabzi polow</a> with <a href="/wiki/Fish_as_food" title="Fish as food">fish</a> (<a href="/wiki/Iran" title="Iran">Iranians</a>): A traditional New Year's Day meal of rice with green herbs, served with fish. The traditional seasonings for sabzi polow are <a href="/wiki/Parsley" title="Parsley">parsley</a>, <a href="/wiki/Coriander" title="Coriander">coriander</a> greens (cilantro), <a href="/wiki/Chives" title="Chives">chives</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dill" title="Dill">dill</a> herb and <a href="/wiki/Fenugreek" title="Fenugreek">fenugreek</a> greens.</li>
</ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Mythology">Mythology</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Nowruz&amp;action=edit&amp;section=37" title="Edit section: Mythology">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Nowruz_Zoroastrian.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/Nowruz_Zoroastrian.jpg/220px-Nowruz_Zoroastrian.jpg" width="220" height="134" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/Nowruz_Zoroastrian.jpg/330px-Nowruz_Zoroastrian.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/Nowruz_Zoroastrian.jpg/440px-Nowruz_Zoroastrian.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2500" data-file-height="1523" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Nowruz_Zoroastrian.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<a href="/wiki/Bas-relief" class="mw-redirect" title="Bas-relief">Bas-relief</a> in Persepolis, depicting a symbol in <a href="/wiki/Zoroastrianism" title="Zoroastrianism">Zoroastrianism</a> for Nowruz.<sup id="cite_ref-134" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-134">[note 1]</a></sup></div>
</div>
</div>
<p>There exist various foundation myths for Nowruz in <a href="/wiki/Iranian_mythology" title="Iranian mythology">Iranian mythology</a>.</p>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Shahnameh" title="Shahnameh">Shahnameh</a> dates Nowruz as far back to the reign of <a href="/wiki/Jamshid" title="Jamshid">Jamshid</a>, who in <a href="/wiki/Zoroastrian" class="mw-redirect" title="Zoroastrian">Zoroastrian</a> texts saved mankind from a killer winter that was destined to kill every living creature.<sup id="cite_ref-135" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-135">[134]</a></sup> Jamshid, the mythical Iranian king, perhaps symbolizes the transition of the Proto-Iranians from animal hunting to <a href="/wiki/Animal_husbandry" title="Animal husbandry">animal husbandry</a> and a more settled life in human history.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (April 2016)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> In the Shahnameh and Iranian mythology, he is credited with the foundation of Nowruz. The book reads that Jamshid constructed a throne studded with gems. He had demons raise him above the earth into the heavens; there he sat on his throne like the sun shining in the sky. The world's creatures gathered in wonder about him and the scattered jewels around him, and called this day the <i>New Day</i> (<i>Now Ruz</i>). This was the first day of <a href="/wiki/Farvardin" title="Farvardin">Farvardin</a>, which is the first month of the <a href="/wiki/Iranian_calendar" class="mw-redirect" title="Iranian calendar">Iranian calendar</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-136" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-136">[135]</a></sup></p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Astronomy">Astronomy</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Nowruz&amp;action=edit&amp;section=38" title="Edit section: Astronomy">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">Main article: <a href="/wiki/March_equinox" title="March equinox">March equinox</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Earth-lighting-equinox_EN.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Earth-lighting-equinox_EN.png/220px-Earth-lighting-equinox_EN.png" width="220" height="144" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Earth-lighting-equinox_EN.png/330px-Earth-lighting-equinox_EN.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Earth-lighting-equinox_EN.png/440px-Earth-lighting-equinox_EN.png 2x" data-file-width="1560" data-file-height="1024" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Earth-lighting-equinox_EN.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
Illumination of Earth by the Sun on the day of an equinox.</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>The first day of the <a href="/wiki/Iranian_calendar" class="mw-redirect" title="Iranian calendar">Iranian calendar</a> falls on the <a href="/wiki/March_equinox" title="March equinox">March equinox</a>, the first day of spring, around 21 March. At the time of the equinox, the sun is observed to be directly over the <a href="/wiki/Equator" title="Equator">equator</a>, and the north and south poles of the Earth lie along the <a href="/wiki/Terminator_(solar)" title="Terminator (solar)">solar terminator</a>. Sunlight is evenly divided between the north and south <a href="/wiki/Sphere" title="Sphere">hemispheres</a>.</p>
<p>In around the 11th century CE, major reforms of the Iranian calendars took place and whose principal purpose were to fix the beginning of the calendar year, i.e. Nowruz, at the vernal equinox. Accordingly, the definition of Nowruz given by the Iranian scientist <a href="/wiki/Nasir_al-Din_al-Tusi" title="Nasir al-Din al-Tusi">Tusi</a> was the following: "the first day of the official New Year [Nowruz] was always the day on which the sun entered <a href="/wiki/Aries_(astrology)" title="Aries (astrology)">Aries</a> before noon."<sup id="cite_ref-137" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-137">[136]</a></sup></p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Calendar">Calendar</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Nowruz&amp;action=edit&amp;section=39" title="Edit section: Calendar">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Nowruz is the first day of <a href="/wiki/Farvardin" title="Farvardin">Farvardin</a>, the first month of the <a href="/wiki/Solar_Hijri_calendar" title="Solar Hijri calendar">Iranian solar calendar</a>.</p>
<p>In the <i>Fasli</i>/<i>Bastani</i> variant of the Zoroastrian calendar, Navroz is always the day of the <a href="/wiki/Vernal_equinox" class="mw-redirect" title="Vernal equinox">vernal equinox</a> (nominally falling on March 21).</p>
<p>In the <i>Shahenshahi</i> and <i>Kadmi</i> calendars, which do not account for leap years, the New Year's Day has drifted ahead by over 200 days. These latter two variants of the calendar, which are only followed by the Zoroastrians of Pakistan and India, celebrate the spring equinox as <i>Jamshed-i Nouroz</i>, with New Year's Day then being celebrated in July–August as <a href="/wiki/Pateti" class="mw-redirect" title="Pateti">Pateti</a> "(day) of penitence" (from <i>patet</i> "confession," hence also repentance and penitence).<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (June 2015)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup></p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Nowruz_in_religions">Nowruz in religions</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Nowruz&amp;action=edit&amp;section=40" title="Edit section: Nowruz in religions">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Apart from Zoroastrianism,<sup id="cite_ref-138" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-138">[137]</a></sup> Nowruz has been entered into the contexts of some other religions and faiths.</p>
<p>There exist narrations in the <a href="/wiki/Shia_Islam" title="Shia Islam">Shia</a> literature about the merits of the day of Nowruz, including that the <a href="/wiki/The_event_of_Ghadir_Khumm" title="The event of Ghadir Khumm">Day of Ghadir</a> was on that day, and also the recommendation to fast on the day of Nowruz, the latter appearing in the fatwas of major Shia scholars.<sup id="cite_ref-139" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-139">[138]</a></sup></p>
<p>Nowruz is also a holy day for <a href="/wiki/Sufism" title="Sufism">Sufis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bektashis" class="mw-redirect" title="Bektashis">Bektashis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ismailism" class="mw-redirect" title="Ismailism">Ismailis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Alawites" title="Alawites">Alawites</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-i-cias.com_140-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-i-cias.com-140">[139]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Alevism" title="Alevism">Alevis</a>, <a href="/wiki/B%C3%A1bism" title="Bábism">Babis</a> and adherents of the <a href="/wiki/Bah%C3%A1%27%C3%AD_Faith" title="Bahá'í Faith">Bahá'í Faith</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-bahai_calendar_141-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bahai_calendar-141">[140]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Bah.C3.A1.27.C3.AD_Faith">Bahá'í Faith</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Nowruz&amp;action=edit&amp;section=41" title="Edit section: Bahá'í Faith">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Bah%C3%A1%27%C3%AD_Naw-R%C3%BAz" title="Bahá'í Naw-Rúz">Bahá'í Naw-Rúz</a></div>
<p>Naw-Rúz is one of nine holy days for adherents of the <a href="/wiki/Bah%C3%A1%27%C3%AD_Faith" title="Bahá'í Faith">Bahá'í Faith</a> worldwide. It is the first day of the <a href="/wiki/Bah%C3%A1%27%C3%AD_calendar" title="Bahá'í calendar">Bahá'í calendar</a>, occurring on the vernal equinox around March 21.<sup id="cite_ref-walbridge_142-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-walbridge-142">[141]</a></sup> The Bahá'í calendar is composed of 19 months, each of 19 days,<sup id="cite_ref-bne_143-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bne-143">[142]</a></sup> and each of the months is named after an attribute of God; similarly each of the nineteen days in the month also are named after an attribute of God.<sup id="cite_ref-bne_143-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bne-143">[142]</a></sup> The first day and the first month were given the attribute of <a href="/wiki/Bah%C3%A1%27%C3%AD_symbols#Bah.C3.A1.E2.80.99" title="Bahá'í symbols">Bahá</a>, an <a href="/wiki/Arabic_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabic language">Arabic</a> word meaning splendour or glory, and thus the first day of the year was the day of Bahá in the month of Bahá.<sup id="cite_ref-walbridge_142-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-walbridge-142">[141]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-lehman_144-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-lehman-144">[143]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Bah%C3%A1%27u%27ll%C3%A1h" title="Bahá'u'lláh">Bahá'u'lláh</a>, the founder of the Bahá'í Faith, explained that Naw-Rúz was associated with the <i>Most Great Name</i> of God,<sup id="cite_ref-walbridge_142-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-walbridge-142">[141]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-lehman_144-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-lehman-144">[143]</a></sup> and was instituted as a festival for those who observed the <a href="/wiki/Nineteen_day_fast" class="mw-redirect" title="Nineteen day fast">Nineteen day fast</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-prayers_145-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-prayers-145">[144]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-aqdas_146-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-aqdas-146">[145]</a></sup></p>
<p>The day is also used to symbolize the renewal of time in each religious dispensation.<sup id="cite_ref-iranica_147-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-iranica-147">[146]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/%60Abdu%27l-Bah%C3%A1" title="`Abdu'l-Bahá">`Abdu'l-Bahá</a>, Bahá'u'lláh's son and successor, explained that significance of Naw-Rúz in terms of <a href="/wiki/Spring_(season)" title="Spring (season)">spring</a> and the new life it brings.<sup id="cite_ref-walbridge_142-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-walbridge-142">[141]</a></sup> He explained that the equinox is a symbol of the <a href="/wiki/Manifestation_of_God" title="Manifestation of God">messengers of God</a> and the message that they proclaim is like a spiritual springtime, and that Naw-Rúz is used to commemorate it.<sup id="cite_ref-148" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-148">[147]</a></sup></p>
<p>As with all Bahá'í holy days, there are few fixed rules for observing Naw-Rúz, and Bahá'ís all over the world celebrate it as a festive day, according to local custom.<sup id="cite_ref-walbridge_142-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-walbridge-142">[141]</a></sup> Persian Bahá'ís still observe many of the Iranian customs associated with Nowruz such as the Haft Seen, but American Bahá'í communities, for example, may have a <a href="/wiki/Potluck_dinner" class="mw-redirect" title="Potluck dinner">potluck dinner</a>, along with prayers and readings from <a href="/wiki/Bah%C3%A1%27%C3%AD_literature" title="Bahá'í literature">Bahá'í scripture</a>.</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Twelver_Shia_faith_and_Shia_Ismaili_faith">Twelver Shia faith and Shia Ismaili faith</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Nowruz&amp;action=edit&amp;section=42" title="Edit section: Twelver Shia faith and Shia Ismaili faith">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Along with Ismailis,<sup id="cite_ref-149" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-149">[148]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-150" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-150">[149]</a></sup> Alawites and Alevis, the <a href="/wiki/Twelver" title="Twelver">Twelver Shia</a> also hold the day of Nowruz in high regard.</p>
<p>It has been said that <a href="/wiki/Musa_al-Kadhim" title="Musa al-Kadhim">Musa al-Kadhim</a>, the seventh <a href="/wiki/Shia" class="mw-redirect" title="Shia">Shia</a> <a href="/wiki/Imam" title="Imam">imam</a>, has explained Nowruz and said: "In Nowruz God made a covenant with His servants to worship Him and not to allow any partner for Him. To welcome, His messengers and obey their rulings. This day is the rst day that the fertile wind blow and the owers on the earth appeared. The archangel <a href="/wiki/Gabriel" title="Gabriel">Gabriel</a> appeared to the <a href="/wiki/Muhammad" title="Muhammad">Prophet</a>, and it is the day that <a href="/wiki/Abraham" title="Abraham">Abraham</a> broke the <a href="/wiki/Idolatry" title="Idolatry">idols</a>. The day Prophet Muhammad held <a href="/wiki/Ali" title="Ali">Ali</a> on his shoulders to destroy the Quraishie's idols in the house of God, the <a href="/wiki/Kaaba" title="Kaaba">Kaaba</a>."<sup id="cite_ref-151" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-151">[150]</a></sup></p>
<p>The day upon which Nowruz falls has been recommended as a day of fasting for Twelver Shia Muslims by Shia scholars, including <a href="/wiki/Abu_al-Qasim_al-Khoei" title="Abu al-Qasim al-Khoei">Abu al-Qasim al-Khoei</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ruhollah_Khomeini" title="Ruhollah Khomeini">Ruhollah Khomeini</a><sup id="cite_ref-152" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-152">[151]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Ali_al-Sistani" title="Ali al-Sistani">Ali al-Sistani</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-153" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-153">[152]</a></sup> The day also assumes special significance for Shias as it has been said that it was on 21&#160;March 656&#160;AD that the first Shia Imam, Ali, assumed the office of caliphate.</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">See also</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Nowruz&amp;action=edit&amp;section=43" title="Edit section: See also">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<ul>
<li><a href="/wiki/Tammuz_(deity)" title="Tammuz (deity)">Tammuz (deity)</a></li>
</ul>
<div role="navigation" aria-label="Portals" class="noprint portal plainlist tright" style="margin:0.5em 0 0.5em 1em;border:solid #aaa 1px">

<li style="display:table-row"><span style="display:table-cell;padding:0.2em;vertical-align:middle;text-align:center"><a href="/wiki/File:Calendar_icon.svg" class="image"><img alt="icon" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Calendar_icon.svg/22px-Calendar_icon.svg.png" width="22" height="28" class="noviewer" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Calendar_icon.svg/33px-Calendar_icon.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Calendar_icon.svg/44px-Calendar_icon.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="720" data-file-height="920" /></a></span><span style="display:table-cell;padding:0.2em 0.2em 0.2em 0.3em;vertical-align:middle"><a href="/wiki/Portal:Holidays" title="Portal:Holidays">Holidays portal</a></span></li>
</ul>
</div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Nowruz&amp;action=edit&amp;section=44" title="Edit section: Notes">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<div class="reflist" style="list-style-type: decimal;">
<ol class="references">
<li id="cite_note-134"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-134">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Eternally fighting bull (personifying the moon), and a lion (personifying the sun) representing the spring.</span></li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Nowruz&amp;action=edit&amp;section=45" title="Edit section: References">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<div class="reflist columns references-column-width" style="-moz-column-width: 30em; -webkit-column-width: 30em; column-width: 30em; list-style-type: decimal;">
<ol class="references">
<li id="cite_note-komunitetibektashi.org-1"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-komunitetibektashi.org_1-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-komunitetibektashi.org_1-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.komunitetibektashi.org/in.php?fq=brenda&amp;gj=gj1&amp;kid=1">"The World Headquarters of the Bektashi Order&#160;– Tirana, Albania"</a>. komunitetibektashi.org<span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-www.iranicaonline.org-5"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-www.iranicaonline.org_5-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-www.iranicaonline.org_5-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/nowruz-ii/">"Nowruz observed in Indian subcontinent"</a>. www.iranicaonline.org<span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-27"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-27">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://sabzalipour.iaurasht.ac.ir/faculty/Files/111/Staff/Faculty/111_2015-11-22_04.23.07_cv%20sabzalipour%2094.pdf">"Farhang-e Tti, Jahandoost Sabzalipour, Rasht: Farhang-e Iliya Press. <li id="cite_note-45"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-45">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Andrew L. Sihler (<b>1995</b>) <i>New Comparative Grammar of Greek and Latin</i>, New York, Oxford, Oxford University Press</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-46"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-46">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Julius Pokorny (<b>1959</b>), <i>Indogermanisches etymologisches Wörterbuch</i>, in 3 vols, Bern, München: Francke Verlag</span></li>
